title: Were the Minnesota Vikings the most unorthodox team in the 2022 season?
text: The Minnesota Vikings may have had one of the craziest seasons of all time last season. To give a brief overview, they won the NFC North, finished with a 13-4 record, and completed the largest comeback in NFL history, defeating the Indianapolis Colts 39-36, after going down 33-0 at halftime. The million-dollar question that I used different graphs and data from Pro Football Reference to find the answer to is: Were the Minnesota Vikings the most unorthodox team in the NFL last season? My simple answer: yes. It is a miracle they won as many games as they did because based off the numbers they produced; they should have been maybe .500, but definitely not 13-4. They had one of the worst defenses in the NFL and having Kirk Cousins as their quarterback doesn’t help matters much either. Code library(tidyverse) library(ggrepel) library(ggalt) library(ggtext) teamrecord <- read_csv("teamrecord.csv") vikingstats <- teamrecord %>% filter(Tm == "Minnesota Vikings") winners <- teamrecord %>% filter(W >= 13) %>% filter(Tm != "Minnesota Vikings") nfloffense <- read_csv("nfloffense") nfldefense <- read_csv("nfldefense_csv") ggplot() + geom_point( data=teamrecord, aes(x=PF, y=PA, size=W), color="grey", alpha=.4) + geom_point( data=vikingstats, aes(x=PF, y=PA, size=W), color="purple") + geom_text_repel( data=vikingstats, aes(x=PF, y=PA + 12.5, label=Tm) )+ geom_point( data=winners, aes(x=PF, y=PA, size=W), color="black", alpha=.5) + geom_text_repel( data=winners, aes(x=PF, y=PA + 12.5, label=Tm) ) + labs( x="Points Scored", y="Points Allowed", title="The gap between the Vikings and teams with a chance to go far", subtitle="Although Minnesota scored a lot of points, they gave up close to the most in the NFL.", caption="Source: Pro Football Reference | By Avery Peck" )+ theme_classic() + theme( plot.title.position = "plot", plot.title=element_text(size=16, face = "bold"), plot.subtitle= element_text(size=11) ) elkjrglkdjfglkdjflgkjdflkjg Code OFturnovers<- nfloffense %>% select(Tm, TO) %>% rename(OffensiveTurnovers=TO) Defturnovers<- nfldefense %>% select(Tm, TO) %>% rename(DefensiveTurnovers=TO) turnovers <- OFturnovers %>% inner_join(Defturnovers) vikingturnovers <- turnovers %>% filter(Tm == "Minnesota Vikings") ggplot() + geom_dumbbell( data=turnovers, aes(y=reorder(Tm, DefensiveTurnovers), x=DefensiveTurnovers, xend=OffensiveTurnovers), size = 2, colour = "grey", colour_x = "#013220", colour_xend = "#8b0000") + geom_dumbbell( data=vikingturnovers, aes(y=reorder(Tm, DefensiveTurnovers), x=DefensiveTurnovers, xend=OffensiveTurnovers), size = 2, colour = "purple", colour_x = "#013220", colour_xend = "#8b0000") + theme( plot.subtitle = element_textbox_simple() ) + labs( x= "Turnovers", y= "", title="Offensive and Defensive Turnovers", subtitle ="When the defense takes the ball away more than the offense gives the ball away, they usually win.", caption="Source: Pro Football Reference | By Avery Peck" ) + theme_classic() + theme( plot.title.position = "plot", plot.title=element_text(size=16, face = "bold"), plot.subtitle= element_textbox_simple(size=11) ) sldkjfgslknjvlkdjfglkdjfglkjd Code ggplot() + geom_bar(data=teamrecord, aes(x= reorder(Tm, PD), weight=PD), fill= "light grey") + geom_bar(data=winners, aes(x= reorder(Tm, PD), weight=PD), fill="dark grey") + geom_bar(data=vikingstats, aes(x= reorder(Tm, PD), weight=PD), fill="purple") + geom_text(aes(x="Minnesota Vikings", y=67, label="<- This team made the playoffs")) + coord_flip() + labs( x= "", y="Point Differential", title= "The Vikes had a negative point differential, yet won 13 games", subtitle="They won 13 games for the second time in franchise history. But, Minnesota was also outscored by a \nfield goal over the course of the 2022-2023 season.", caption="Source: Pro Football Reference | By Avery Peck" ) + theme_classic() + theme( plot.title.position = "plot", plot.title=element_text(size=16, face = "bold"), plot.subtitle= element_text(size=11) )

title: R Notebook
text:
This is an R Markdown Notebook. When you execute code within the notebook, the results appear beneath the code.
Try executing this chunk by clicking the Run button within the chunk or by placing your cursor inside it and pressing Cmd+Shift+Enter.

plot(cars)




Add a new chunk by clicking the Insert Chunk button on the toolbar or by pressing Cmd+Option+I.
When you save the notebook, an HTML file containing the code and output will be saved alongside it (click the Preview button or press Cmd+Shift+K to preview the HTML file).
The preview shows you a rendered HTML copy of the contents of the editor. Consequently, unlike Knit, Preview does not run any R code chunks. Instead, the output of the chunk when it was last run in the editor is displayed.
